meanings.definition: To persuade someone to commit a crime or wrongdoing.
meanings.sent1: The criminal was suborning his partner to help with the robbery.
meanings.sent2: The corrupt official was caught suborning witnesses to lie in court.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous student joked about suborning his classmates into skipping class.
meanings.sent4: The evil mastermind was suborning his minions to carry out his sinister plans.
meanings.sent5: The manipulative villain was suborning innocent people into breaking the law.

meanings.definition: To induce someone to give false testimony.
meanings.sent1: The lawyer was accused of suborning a witness to lie on the stand.
meanings.sent2: The defendant's attempt to suborn perjury was quickly discovered.
meanings.sent3: The comedian joked about suborning his friend to tell a funny story.
meanings.sent4: The politician was suborning the witness to twist the truth in his favor.
meanings.sent5: The detective uncovered a plot to suborn false testimony in the trial.

meanings.definition: To bribe or corrupt someone to do something illegal.
meanings.sent1: The businessman was suborning officials to secure illegal contracts.
meanings.sent2: The criminal organization was suborning police officers to turn a blind eye.
meanings.sent3: The children playfully pretended to be suborning each other to break the rules.
meanings.sent4: The corrupt politician was suborning his colleagues to pass unethical laws.
meanings.sent5: The drug lord was suborning individuals to smuggle illegal substances.
